narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I left the class feeling I had a good pulse on important introductory texts.

I gained insight into how the study of societies can be approached from many different angles and grew familiar with the approaches that have been fundamental to the field of sociology. I also learned how to engage with sociological texts in verbal and written discussion, and to begin formulating my own sociological theories.

This class gives an overview of major themes in sociological though and introduces to students to some classic sociological texts. This provides a strong introduction to the major theoretical traditions within sociology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: inspiring discussions; high-quality student presentations; a well-selected book list
Meeting in Calhoun made a huge difference, in a positive way. It was a place that made me want to think.

The texts were expertly chosen for this course, as they both built off and refuted each other in ways that were fascinating and elucidated the fundamental tensions and goals of the discipline. They were thus canonical without going unchallenged, furnishing a fundamental knowledge of sociology and an ability to handle this knowledge critically. The writing assignments were also well-spaced and thought out - they led me to reflect deeply on the texts and my own emerging ideas throughout the course in ways that a single final essay wouldn't have allowed. I also appreciated the highly interactive nature of the course. I found it a bit hard personally to engage though in part because I didn't feel well enough in command of the texts and their arguments. This was partly my fault - I could have been more efficient in studying them - but I would suggest that the instructor alerts the students well in advance of the sessions specific parts of the text to become intimately familiar with, and then guide the thrust of the discussion towards unpacking the fundaments of the arguments. As most students were new to the field, our contributions tended to be a bit too aimless and easily critical, and we could probably have used some more focus.

It is quite easy to free ride in this class since it is discussion based. You kind of get out of it whatever you want to get out of it. If you thoughtfully read the texts you will get a lot out of it otherwise you probably won't. As well given that this course is discussion based, if you don't feel comfortable speaking in class others will not benefit as much from your insight. The presentations do some to encourage engagement, but there is probably more that can be done. As well please try to post the recommended sections of texts further in advance, without that the readings can get quite out of hand.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: it is a very useful course for students who are interested in sociology to construct a solid theoretical framework
I absolutely would! Dr. Adams is incredible!

This was a great introduction to sociology, and I believe the same would hold true for anybody else who wanted to become familiar with foundational theoretical approaches and comfortable discussing them.
